Can he hit civilians

I haven't specifically tried to but it hasn't happened accidentally either so I'm gonna go with no.

How have you been enjoying the combat, comparatively to Nioh/Nioh 2(assuming you've played them of course)?

How is it difficulty-wise? I love Nioh 1&2, but I kinda hope Ronin is a bit less challenging, so I can focus more on exploring and absorbing the world.

I think I've played the demos of both Nioh games but not more than that. The combat here is similar in that each weapon type has different fighting styles that you can learn, and enemies can be weak, resistant or neutral to them. There is also ki, which is used up by blocking/dodging/attacking. If you get hit when your ki is empty you get staggered, and the same is true for your enemies.

There's a parry mechanic which is integral. Parrying an enemy greatly reduces their ki, doing it well enough or consistently enough allows you to do a Sekiro-style brutal attack (or whatever they're called). Very satisfying.

I'd say in general the combat is way more challenging than the likes of similar open-world games (Assassin's Creed for example). However, I would also say the freedom allowed to you here in terms of how you approach a situation i.e. stealth kills (which are one-shot on weaker enemies), rifles/bows, and NPCs helping you out makes it manageable. There are also set levels, so you can always skip an area and come back later and decimate everyone.

How's the open world? Does the game benefit in anyway from pursuing this direction instead of linear level design? Or does it mostly feel like filler?

This is a tricky one to answer as I think it will largely depend on what you like in open-world games. I would describe it as similar to Assassin's Creed or Ghost of Tsushima. There are cats to find, shrines to pray at, hidden chests, tough fugitive enemies to take out, etc. I'm having fun though, moving around with your horse and the glider makes traversal fun and it never feels like you're slogging through huge open nothingness.

The map is broken up into sections and you have a 'bond' with each region, as you rest at banners (bonfire checkpoints) you gradually reveal more things on the map to find which increases your bond. I wanna say that certain quests and characters wont show up at all until your bond in a region is high enough but I may be wrong about that.

Ultimately if this ends up being Assassin's Creed with good, challenging combat I'm satisfied lol, and so far that seems to be what this is.

How the player character works: You create a male and female character and can choose which one to continue with when they are split up (presumably early on and for a large part of the game).

Arekkz Gaming said:

You start the game off making two characters: a male and female who are twins. (1:10)

Geek Culture said:

In the opening chapters, players will be able to cycle between their Twin Blades mid-combat. It doesn't feel all that different from the genre's party-switching mechanics, but proves to be fluid and satisfying. Up until a certain point, they are forced to pick one half of the pair to continue the narrative with, and the seamlessness extends to controlling allies past the fateful plot point as well.

Geek Preview: Team Ninja’s ‘Rise of the Ronin’ Marks Promising First Foray Into An Open-World Samurai Epic | Geek Culture

I mean I like those games myself but I feel Wo Long veered into a direction where they seem to be listening to people that want team ninja games to just be different games and it feels like it's losing a lot of the unique and interesting things along the way and I don't get the sense that it's paying off. On my side it's just kinda lessening my interest despite me being immensely hopeful to be wrong cause it's team ninja. Cowboy says at the end the cope is still there that the combat evolves much more further in but I dunno the Nioh demo's kinda cemented pretty fast how goated that combat could be.

Like the ideal is always for them to kinda manage to keep the things that feel like the identity that made their previous games big and build on that.

Kinda like how Bloodborne nor Sekiro didn't really veer too far off what the fromsoft games were that brought them the success.

But it just feels like increasingly team ninja is just trying to make a different type of game but then they're also gonna enter a very different arena of comparisons.
